page.title: 02The Landscape of Felton Area
page.content: This area is one of low lying, gently ridged topography, entirely underlain by folded reddish-brown mudstones with some thin sandstones and nodular calcareous beds of the Devonian Series. The area is crossed diagonally by the alluvial flats of the Little Lugg River. The soils are silty loams of the Bromyard Series, suitable for mixed farming. The higher ridges have deciduous woodland on steeper slopes. Elsewhere woodland has been reduced, but field boundaries contain mature small-leaved lime trees, ash, oak and sycamore. The elm has everywhere died out although some natural regeneration may be occuring. Field sizes vary from five acres up to forty acres. There are a number of scattered farms and parts of five minor settlements.
